description: From Middle English hade, had, hod, hed, from Old English hÄd (â€œperson, individual, character, individuality, degree, rank, order, office, holy office, condition, state, nature, character, form, manner, sex, race, family, tribe, choirâ€), from Proto-Germanic *haiduz (â€œappearance, kindâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)kÄy- (â€œlight, bright, shiningâ€). Cognate with Old Saxon hÄ“d (â€œcondition, rankâ€), Old High German heit (â€œperson, personality, sex, condition, quality, rankâ€), Old Norse heiÃ°r ("honour, dignity") (whence Danish hÃ¦der (â€œhonourâ€), Swedish heder (â€œhonourâ€)), Gothic ğŒ·ğŒ°ğŒ¹ğŒ³ğŒ¿ğƒ (haidus, â€œway, mannerâ€). Same as -hood.

entries.meaning: (now chiefly dialectal, Scotland) State; order, estate, rank, degree, or quality.

description: Uncertain. Perhaps from a dialectal form of head.

entries.meaning: (geology) A slope; (in mining) the slope of a vein, fault or dike from the vertical; the complement of the dip.
examples: The thick and well-growne fogge doth matt my smoother shades,
And on the  lower Leas, as on the higher Hades
The daintie Clover growes (of grass the onely silke)
That makes each Udder strout abundantly with milke.

verbs.description: hade (third-person singular simple present hades, present participle hading, simple past and past participle haded)

entries.meaning: (geology, mining) To slope or incline from the vertical.
examples: It was found, however, that where the coal haded away from the floor towards the  face, as in Fig. 2(6), [...]

description: Probably a dialectal or variant form of head.

entries.meaning: (Britain, dialects, obsolete) A headland; a strip of land at the side of a field upon which a plough may be turned.
examples: [...] certeine arable landes some of them havinge hades of meadow and grasse grounde lieinge in the Southe fielde of Einsham.
